term: A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush
def: It is better to be satisfied with something you have than to risk losing it by trying to get something better you may not succeed in getting.

term: Absence makes the heart grow fonder
def: The longer someone is away, the more you realize how much you love or miss them.
What someone actually does means more than what they say they will do.
Even if you are late with a commitment, it's still important to follow through.

term: Do unto others as you would have them do unto you
def: The golden rule.  Treat others as you would like to be treated.

term: Don't put the cart before the horse
def: Don't do things out of the proper order.
To increase one's knowledge by experience, often by making mistakes.
To tolerate the opinions and behavior of others, as you lead the life you want.
Don't worry if you haven't heard; you can assume that all is well.

term: Slow but steady wins the race
def: Consistent and concerted effort leads to success.

term: Two wrongs don't make a right
def: Responding to a misdeed in kind is not appropriate.

term: When in Rome, do as the Romans do
def: In an unfamiliar country or situation, you should follow the lead of the local or experienced people.
Rumors or rumbles tend to indicate much larger problems.

term: A penny saved is a penny earned
def: Spend money wisely.
Problems that occur along the way don't matter as long as the outcome is positive.
People tend to work, live and spend time with others who are similar.

term: Don't count your chickens before they hatch
def: Don't rely on something good happening until it has actually happened.

term: Let's cross that bridge when we come to it
def: Don't worry about potential problems, rather face problems as they come.

term: Out of sight, out of mind
def: You soon forget people or things that are no longer visible or present.

term: Rome wasn't built in a day
def: Important work takes time.

term: The early bird catches the worm
def: The person who is first has the advantage.

term: The grass is always greener on the other side of the fence
def: Other people's situations always seem better than your own.
Problems or bad outcomes tend to occur in clusters.

term: Where there's a will, there's a way
def: If someone is really committed to something, there's a way to make it happen.

term: You can't have your cake and eat it too
def: You can't have it both ways.

term: A man is known by the company he keeps
def: Our character is reflected in our choice of friends.
When we wait impatiently, it seems to take longer.

term: All's fair in love and war
def: In highly charged situations, any method of achieving your objective is justifiable.

term: An apple a day keeps the doctor away
def: Eating nutritious food, and other simple preventions, helps keep you healthy.

term: Don't judge a book by its cover
def: You shouldn't prejudge people or things by their outward appearance.

term: Early to bed and early to rise makes a man healthy, wealthy, and wise
def: Benjamin Franklin's advice for success.
Don't rush through a task as you will make mistakes that take more time and resources.

term: If at first you don't succeed, try, try again
def: Be persistent, even if you face early setbacks.

term: If the shoe fits, wear it
def: If it applies to you, accept it.

term: If you can't stand the heat, get out of the kitchen
def: If you cannot handle the pressure, you should not remain in a position where you have to deal with it.

term: Imitation is the sincerest form of flattery
def: To imitate someone is to pay the person a genuine, often unintended, compliment.

term: It's never over till it's over
def: Even if it's going well, there's no guarantee of success until it's final.

term: Lightning never strikes twice in the same place
def: Rare situations or events are unlikely to happen again in exactly the same circumstances or to the same person.
Before you act, consider the possible consequences or dangers.

term: One rotten apple spoils the barrel
def: A negative or bad person influences everyone he or she comes into contact with.
Even when hard to believe, when you see it for yourself, you are convinced.

term: The bad workman always blames his tools
def: Blaming external factors, rather than take responsibility for their own poor work.

term: The pen is mightier than the sword
def: Communicating is more effective than fighting.
Despite mishaps, you should continue on as planned.

term: There are plenty of fish in the sea
def: There are plenty of good alternatives.

term: Too many cooks spoil the broth
def: If too many people are doing or managing an activity, it will not turn out well.

term: Two heads are better than one
def: It's helpful to have the advice or opinion of a another person.

term: What's good for the goose is good for the gander
def: If one person is allowed to do something, then everyone should be allowed.

term: When the going gets tough, the tough get going
def: In difficult situations, the strong rise to the occasion.
Some situations are irreversible.

term: You can't teach an old dog news tricks
def: People who have long been used to doing things in a particular way will not modify their habits.

term: His bark is worse than his bite
def: Someone may sound frightening, but they are actually harmless.

term: A fool and his money are soon parted
def: It's easy to waste money and it is foolish to do so.
Someone who buys a product or service for personal use.
An organization owned by shareholders, or in the case of nonprofits, accountable to members.
The system of money, especially banknotes, in use in a particular country.  More generally any form of money in use as a medium of exchange.
Money that is owed.
The amount of goods or services that individuals and corporations are willing to purchase at a given price.
The social science that studies the production, distribution, and consumption of goods and services.
A person that starts a business or other venture.
The currency in Europe which replaced the national currencies of Germany, France, Spain, Italy and in total 19 of the 28 member states of the European Union.
Money received for work or through investments in a given period of time, often monthly or annually.
Spending money for something with expectation that its value will rise over time.
The lowest hourly wage permitted by law.

A loan for a home or other real estate property.  It is a specialized loan where the bank takes temporary title (ownership) of the property until the loan and interest are repaid, at which time the title reverts to the buyer.
Materials from nature, such as oil, wood or minerals, which can be developed for economic gain.
Selling goods directly to individual consumers.
For businesses, the income from sales of products and services over a period of time.  For governments, the total income from taxes and fees over a given period.
Work performed for others.
The amount of goods or services available and the quantity desired.
Money collected by the government from individuals and businesses to pay for programs and services.
Generally, the buying and selling of goods and services, or similar economic activity.
The official currency of the United States.
The direct exchange of goods and services for other goods and services, rather than for money.
Large corporations or large-scale commercial or financial activity.
Wealth in the form of money or other assets available for investment.
Money, goods or services which are obtained with an agreement to pay for them the future.
